section.title: Checking In
section.para: The check-in procedure is a members' initial experience with the net, and happens to be a place where the different nets vary widely. Differences in expectation among net members during the check in procedure often cause confusion and wasted time. This is an area where most nets should strive to be as consistent as possible.

section.title: Preamble
section.para: Most nets have some sort of a preamble, ranging from fairly terse to quite lengthy. The preamble does serve to welcome passers-by to the net and to establish the net purpose.

Net Managers might take some time to evaluate whether their preamble really serves the net. For a hard-core traffic net is a lengthy preamble really all that productive? For a net with a more social purpose, does the preamble serve as an invitation to new members? Nets might consider how appropriate their preamble is to their objectives. This is a place where diversity might be welcomed, but nets should periodically evaluate their preamble against the net objectives, and be willing to change when appropriate.

Once having become comfortable that the preamble is appropriate, net managers should be sure that all net controls or potential net controls have access to the agreed upon preamble. Many nets have websites that could provide a reference location for net controls; if not, the STM would be happy to provide space on the mi-nts website.

section.title: Sequence
section.para: The order in which check-ins are requested is something that varies greatly from net to net, and, in the opinion of the STM, is not a place where diversity is useful or welcome.

The following order is proposed as a standard (phone proceures shown):
Is there any emergency or priority traffic?
Are there any mobile, portable, QRP or light copy stations for the net?
Do we have a liaison from The Michigan Net? Repeat for each net which typically sends a liaison.
Are there any liaisons I did not call or who are late in arriving?
Are there any announcements for the net
Are there any stations with Training Topics for the net? (Training topics and announcements should be listed early, but not passed until later. Typically, announcements should be passed before routine traffic but after all checkins, training topics after all traffic has been passed.)
Stations with traffic and traffic only, call signs only please After obtaining a list of stations with traffic, NCS should then ask each station to list traffic: KB8QWQ please list
Are there any stations with or without traffic?
Over Out The Over and Out prosigns are generally omitted during the checkin procedure as the very specific wording used makes them redundant. The exception is when a checkin is listing traffic; the end of the list should be marked by Over since the station expects NCS to confirm they have the list.

CW CW procedures are slightly different. CW tends to be quite terse, so the time spent can be quite short on some things. On CW, general checkins send a single character, usually the first character of their suffix. NCS then queries that station by sending the character, and the station then sends their callsign followed by their traffic rather than listing seperately. Net liaisons respond by immediately sending their callsign and traffic.

The one inefficiency introduced in CW nets is the greeting.
NCS: E/P QTC? K
QNI: GE JOE DE KC8PMX QTC LANSING 1 P K
NCS: KC8PMX GE RYAN R AS QSP LANSING P? K
NCS: QNI M/P/QRP? K
NCS: MVTN REP K
QNI: DE KC8RTW GE JOE QRU K
NCS: KC8RTW GE PAT AS
CW nets do not ask for late or uncalled liaisons. However, liaisons who are late joining will repond to the call for general QNI with a note that they represent a net, for example:
DE K0VP/8RN GE JOE QRU K
Similarly, if an important downstream net, particularly Eighth Region or NWS, is missing, a station may volunteer to go to that net:
DE K8AE VOL NWS GE JOE QRU K
QNC? K
On CW nets, training topics are generally introduced as QNCs. Since traffic is often handled off-frequency on CW nets, net control needs to plan the QNC for a time when all or most stations are checked in, and all are on frequency.
On CW, nets do not ask for stations with and without traffic separately. Because most stations operate QSK or semi-QSK, several stations may check in almost simultaneously and NCS can often handle it. General checkins will also indicate their ability to handle already listed traffic.
NCS: QNI K
QNI: S
QNI: R
NCS: R
QNI: DE KB8RWG GE JOE QTC SAGINAW 1 QSP TAWAS K
NCS: KB8RWG GE KELLY R AS
NCS: S
QNI: GE JOE DE W8SN QRU K
NCS: W8SN GE STAN AS
On CW, NCS may immediately send stations off frequency to pass traffic:
QNI: DE KB8RWG GE JOE QTC SAGINAW 1 QSP TAWAS K
NCS: GE KELLY KB8RWG ES K8SB
K8SB: T
NCS: UP 3 UP 3 TAWAS 1 K
KB8RWG: G
K8SB: G
NCS: TU

section.title: This Is
section.para: It has become common practice on phone to follow the MARS procedure of saying This is, releasing the microphone for a second, and then following with a call. While there may be some utility on MARS circuits, on amateur circuits this procedure offers little or no benefit, and merely wastes time and adds confusion.

On SSB, net control can tell there is a double, and in most cases can identify both stations. Since This is and most call signs take almost identical amounts of time with most speakers, neither transmitting station realizes they are doubling since on phone, unlike CW, stations cannot hear while they are transmitting.

On FM repeaters, the situation is further aggravated by the long transmit turnaround delays on the repeater, and the further annoyance of the beep almost guaranteeing that the two stations are going to transmit at identical times.
Some slight advantage might be gained on FM or AM simplex circuits, although it seems unlikely.
When net control announces call signs only, please, stations should announce their callsign only, without other adornment or noise words.

section.title: Acknowledgement
section.para: On phone, net control should acknowldege general checkins in as large a group as feasible. In most cases, stations tend to come in groups, so acknowledging stations in groups of 5 or 10 reduces the odds of net control doubling with a checking in station, and saves time.

When conditions are not good, however, it may make sense to acknowledge each checkin individually. When acknowledging checkins individually, net control should strive to be efficient, but still ensure that each station understands they have been recognized. For example: N8OSL roger, next. The check in process can be rather tedious, and it is not the time for net control to stretch the process out with unnecessary comments.

section.title: No Traffic
section.para: When checking in, stations should give their call, and if they have traffic, add with traffic. It has become a common, and poor, practice to say no traffic when a station has no traffic for the net, but this not only spends unnecessary time, but can add confusion. On noisy HF circuits, with traffic and no traffic sound very similar. Much better to simply omit no traffic.
